commentBody: Mommy, mommy, what's a TOLLBOOTH?
Paid no attention to the theme, but loved the experience of solving this puzzle for some ineffable reason which I shall soon explain in detail.

Rebuses again? At least with them in the clues, I hope nobody tries to squish more than one letter in any boxes.

Nice puzzle, Dario.

Easy week continues. This one would have been nice for next Tuesday.
Interesting puzzle. Got ONTHEROAD fairly early and that helped. This was a bottom up solve for me

Sam writes:
   This isn‚Äôt a rebus puzzle...


I'd say the clues for 17A, 24A, 49A and 58A are rebuses.
I ignored the theme and solved around it instead. Y

ON THE ROAD as the first fill helped. 13:20. Way under my average. Seemed real easy for a Thursday. I know many people don‚Äôt want to hear that. Sorry. It was still fun. It‚Äôs nice to be able to feel that it can be a race sometimes.

Breezy puzzle with ACOUPLE of nice clues.  I particularly liked the clue for that old standby ERR.  I confess to solving without bothering to figure out what the graphics in the themed clues, because the revealer and the crosses gave me everything I needed.

OK, I tried my hand at this theme idea. It took 10 minutes to type on my phone, so you only get the one:

|   X      |
|   Y      |
|   X      |
|   Y      |
|   X  Y  |
|   X  Y  |



ZIPPER MERGE
Loved ‚ÄúWithout ‚Äòad-out‚Äô.‚Äù

So, the Rebuses are in the clues today,  I‚Äôm OK with that.

But final go-round being the GUN LAP?  That‚Äôs usually the BELL LAP in my (long) lifetime.  But maybe once upon a time.  Yes, I know it‚Äôs in the dictionary.

Whilst confucian has a Taoist element, the tao is literally the philosophical juxtaposition of the ‚ÄúConfucian way‚Äù, much like the relation between Aristotle and plato. This isn‚Äôt the first time the editors are confused about this.

We print the puzzle and solve it as a small group.  This weeks is v difficult to read.  Could you please go back to the "old" way - if you are unsure what that is, just hit 'print' for yesterday's puzzle.
Thanks.

__________________________
xxxxxxxxxxxx  x
x                   x                    x            
--------------------------------------

(That guy who drives the speed limit in the passing lane and holds everyone up.)

______________________________________
XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
-------------------------------------------------------
XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
__________________.   ___________________
                                    |X|
                                    |X|
(Me trying to go "down-island" on the nicest summer day of the year at Martha's Vineyard, and no one let us in for maybe 20 minutes!)

Too bad there were no hitchhikers, beatniks, dharma bums or other references to Kerouac's masterpiece, but his spirit lives on! Very much liked this puzzle and its road-adjacent words, SPARE, and SLIM JIM -- I only take note of them in gas station stores -- plus GUN LAP, CAR FARE and for all you jeepsters, EAT DIRT. 

_____________________________________________

                                                                                          %
                                                                                           |
    xxxxxxxxxxxxx, "!!!%&(B$*^&#@###!!!"   x         %

_______________________________________________

(Me obliviously texting while stopped at a light, which has turned green, and a bunch of cars behind me are beeping and cursing at me)
Had SLIP but it's a SHAM! Never use it in everyday life. Same for GUNLAP. ü§î Loved the theme though!

I really liked the visual rebus element here. Not sure why, but it reminded me of my early years messing around with our calculators in class to create words with numbers or later our pagers to send funny messages with numbers üòâ Early emails that we sent included ‚Äúimages‚Äù like the theme clues. This puzzle just really made me smile tonight. 
Congratulations on your debut, Dario.
The confluence of ADIN, ADUE, and GUNLAP almost did me in, as I wasn't really familiar with any of these terms. But I got lucky with a few guesses and still beat my Thursday average by 6 minutes.

Two roads diverged near a math class: 
I subtracted one number from the other, 
And that has made all the difference.

(Not the same author, I know - might get a Frosty reception.)

Nice one, Dario! I loved the ASCII art element in the theme clues, which reminded me of old character-graphic games like rogue and nethack ‚Äî and their descendants, like Dwarf Fortress (https://indiewod.com/dwarf-fortress-how-to-understand-the-ascii-visuals). ü§ì Yes, it was a quick solve for a Thursday (13:30) ‚Äî but I also found it challenging every step of the way, and had an especially slow start in the chewy northwest corner.
Two tennis clues and an Italian term crossing a racing clue was rough but the clue for ERR gave me enough of a laugh to make up for it

Down the Garden Path

     & T
 üå∑____üå∑
     üå∑ ____üå∑
         üå∑ _____üå∑
               üå∑______üå∑
                   üå∑_______üå∑
üå∑üå∑üå∑üå∑ üå∑  _________ üå∑üå∑üå∑üå∑üå∑
30A was my favorite clue! Made me laugh, especially so close to 10D
Fun one!  Thursday best for me!

Re 31A, in a former life, I worked on the Central Experimental Farm in Ottawa, Canada.  It was just as its name implies; a huge tract of farmland in the middle of the city where dozens of research scientists worked, seeking ways to breed animals in as efficient a manner as possible.  Chickens were one such group and I learned that there were very skilled workers called ‚Äúchick-sexers‚Äù  most adept at quickly determining the sex of a newly hatched baby chick.

Armed with this knowledge, I happened to be in the audience at an improv evening. One of the performers wanted to demonstrate the group‚Äôs facility in creating sketches on the spot, asking the audience for ideas.  He asked for someone in the audience to name an occupation.  Being clever, so I thought, I called out ‚Äúchick-sexer‚Äù.  Quick as a flash, he shot back, ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt have to be your job!‚Äù
Who else tried Bigfoot for 39 down?
Anybody else have Willie Nelson in their head? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dBN86y30Ufc

For those that solved around the same theme rather than with it, you missed out. Once I had a few crosses and got FREEWAY EXIT, the pictographs immediately became recognizable and cracked the puzzle wide open. I agree with Sam that there is a generation now that did not grow up with ASCII art or emoticons that might not see this right away. It was a pleasant Aha! moment that has been lacking in puzzles of late. I that being said, I still finished this in Wednesday time.
That was fun!  Just what I needed after a not so fun day.  Congratulations on your debut, Dario.  Looking forward to your next one.
Lao-Tzu is the author of the Tao Te Ching, not sure why Confucius was credited.

@Sam L @The X-Phile @SBK @dutchiris      Mann update

Our Settembrini has been missing for a while.  Hope that it's just a routine case of real-life interference and nothing serious.
I've made some progress.  I knew that the Walpurgis Night section would be in French in my edition (as it was in Mann's Zauberberg).  I first tried to get a toehold with my rudimentary French and quickly gave up.  Google Translate worked fine.

Several analyses of the book note the use of the number 7.
1  Castorp was seven when his parents died; 
 2 He stays seven years at the Berghof, 1907 to 1914; 
3 The Walpurgis Night scene happens after seven months, 
4 The dining hall has seven tables, 
5 Madame Chauchat is initially assigned room number 7, 
the digits of Castorp's room number (34) add up to seven, and 
6 Joachim's room is a multiple of seven (28). 
7 Settembrini's name includes 'seven' (sette) in Italian, 
8 The thermometer routine takes seven minutes 
9 Joachim leaves after a stay of seven times seventy days, 
and dies at seven o'clock. 
10 The novel itself, moreover, is divided into seven chapters.

My view is that the allusion is to the Book of Revelation and the opening of the Seventh Seal triggering the Apocalypse. No other source I found mentioned that.  I'll claim it as my own.
Would these things be called "trafficons" ?

userLocation: no longer writing like E. E. Cummings
commentBody:
Crunchiest Thursday in months for me.
Mostly ignored the theme except for TOLLBOOTHS.

I never tuned into the wavelength of the clues - it showed mostly in the NW corner, where I only made progress having looked up OCALA and SALT TAX (I thought Levy would be the name of a guy...), and in the SW corner, where I broke down, checked the puzzle and finally revealed some stuff,

The "Case of emergency?" clue was the perfect example how cultural differences may hinder a solve - while in the US all caps is used for important messages, it is not, over here, because all caps is more difficult to read quickly than lower case letters.

Elsewhere the cluster of the mysterious GUN LAP, A DUE and ADIN was impossible to resolve for me. I actually watch tennis, occasionally, and I'm familiar with "advantage", but ADIN does not ring a bell. I've never heard of a GUN LAP, and I'm hopeless with musical terms. 

I've never read Kerouac and I know nothing about him, really, but somehow I recalled the title, with a few crosses. However, since I've had no personal experience with him or his book, the theme did nothing for me.

I didn't think this was a bad puzzle - it simply proved too difficult for me, and the theme was a miss, for personal reasons.

When ASH from HOTDOGS that flew too close to the flame makes a SLIMJIM sound good, you're likely UPFOR anything.

There's folks what CRAMS a BEARPAW into any jar of pickled eggs at the first STORE nearest the FREEWAYEXIT. (Thems the same what ATEDIRT in gradeschool).

Say, do you know the difference between ALPO and OREOS? 

ASTO me, I ainn't no MAESTRO of fine TASE, but I kin suss SHAM PATE on a saltine. They ADIN who knows what, and you end up with a belly ACHE.  

Why, I heard tell how IRA OCALA (YES, the same IRA at the SPARE PIN ALLY that WEARS ALLCAPS) Well, IRA had ACOUPLE too many at last week's CANASTA game.  He told us he was ONTHEROAD and came OVER in a cold SWAT!  - "YES, DUTY calls, purt near always in a TRAFFICJAM or LANECLOSURE!"

Well, to AERO is human . . .

userLocation: ICE in Italia? Basta, ruffiani! Fuori!
commentBody:
Regrettably, Sam's column today has two infelicities.
First, the rebus clues do not use Wingdings. They are all straight-up ASCII characters.
Second, while the association of CPAs with schedules (55A) could mean 'fee schedules', that's a very green-paint explanation. Surely, what we're talking about here is tax schedules which require CPAs' expertise.
On the plus side, I needed Sam's explanation of ADIN for 34A.  That bloc held me up forever. No idea about GUNLAP, and ADUE still seems wrong to me.

( ^-^)/ ‚Ä¶.
 X      X      X      X
 X      X      X

Pedestrian crossing


X     X     x     X

Pothole
I enjoyed this one! :-)
Oh what fun! Loved the creativity. Thanks for a welcome change.

Is today‚Äôs WP column a pic of someone preparing to paint a thumb or a toenail sketch?üë©üèº‚Äçüé® 
Cue the virtual rimshot please.

Missed opportunity to clue 38D as "Just remember _______ when you spell the man's name" to atone for a recent error regarding MF DOOM.

I understand the style guide and all that, just had to poke some fun :)
Not for me, paper thin theme and some iffy clues. Was a miracle that GUN LAP was the right guess, would have given up if not to avoid running the alphabet on all the proper noun/trivia crosses

This was fun! I caught on with the revealer and |$|$|$|$| (after a few crosses), a plus for any puzzle. It took me a long time in the end to see that ALLCArS (police cars maybe?) and rATE wouldn‚Äôt do.
Great puzzle, thanks!

Fun puzzle definitely, but put me in the boat with the head-scratching ADIN/ADUE/GUNLAP puzzlers. No tennis knowledge, plenty of music knowledge (but never ran across A DUE), and TIL GUNLAP (which I‚Äôll dutifully forget tomorrow) :/

After figuring out ONTHEROAD and FREEWAYEXIT, I was able to figure out all the other themers (with a little help from Google). However, I had no idea what those WingDings were about until I read the Wordplay column.

30A clue for ERR is without a doubt the best one I've seen for that bit of crossword glue. 

I had a tough time with the NW corner. My lone entry was the incorrect levy instead of DUTY in 20A. When 3D had levy in the clue, I was puzzled, but that didn't help at all, cuz I sure didn't know what type of tax funded the Erie Canal. (But an unusual sighting, Erie in the clue, not the answer! Like using Oreo to clue black or something.)

I thought the theme was fun. I didn't have a clue on what it actually was until the crosses started filling in.

What a de-beaut!

Just plain fun.

I resisted (kicked, screamed, refused) 
emoticons, emojis,
all things not traditional text, 
until my son pointed out that I *also*
complained often 
about the lack of context in texting.

He suggested leaning in to this
new language of images 
as a means to communicate 
more clearly when texting.

By gum, the boy-man was right!

I only use five.
So far...
It's THE Shire

Congratulations to Paolo Pasco, who caught fire in the second half of Jeopardy last night, and ran away with the victory, winning the Tournament of Champions, and getting a spot on the Masters tournament.  His broad knowledge, quickness, generous spirit, and that mischievous glint in his eye made him a joy to behold.  Go Paolo!

Man, brilliant. I loved this, until I didn‚Äôt. Not the creator‚Äôs fault however, just 44D making an absolute meal out of me. 

Sped through this. Filled in my last clue. And nothing. Parsed it backwards and forwards. 

CABFARE made so much sense. No idea who the Gershwin brothers are. IBA? Odd name, but sure. Probably some weird old Jewish spelling. 

Legit had to look up the answer key to see where I went wrong. What on earth is a CARFARE???!? Is this some weird American-ism? 

Anyway, great puzzle nonetheless. Super clever theme.

The TRAFFIC JAM clue was unnecessarily cryptic when seen in the NYT app or website, because it shows three slices of road on a single line:

|X:X:X:X| |X:X:X:X| |X:X:X:X|

For the print version, it was laid out like this, which makes more sense:

|X:X:X:X|
|X:X:X:X|
|X:X:X:X|

Kind of a joy ride for me.

Lots of riddles, which I adore ‚Äì not only in translating the visual clues, but also in the regular ones. I found that several times I had to run the alphabet to figure out the last square in an answer.  That, to me, is a sign of s good clue/answer.

Interesting answers too, from a wide range of fields: SHAM, SHIRE, ALL CAPS, BEAR PAW, CANASTA, CHINO, HELIXES, MAESTRO.

CAR FARE (44D) could have been the puzzle title.

Lovely clues, such as [Case of emergency] for ALL CAPS, and [Paragraph starter, perhaps] for TAB, but my favorite was [Mistake ‚Äúair‚Äù for ‚Äúheir‚Äù, say] for ERR, with those two ‚Äúerr‚Äù soundalikes ‚Äì so dang clever, and furthermore, ERR has been in the major crossword outlets more than a thousand times ‚Äì you‚Äôd think all the clues would have been thought of ‚Äì but this is a clue debut!

All this plus some brain-loving speed bumps made for a splendid outing.  Thank you for that, Dario, and congratulations on your NYT debut puzzle!

I always scan the entire puzzle to see the gimmes, very easy on the printed page. Though I was a little kid when ON THE ROAD was published, I was enough of a hippie later on to be able to fill this in without a thought as my first answer, which made the theme answers a little easier to decipher. But except for TOLLBOOTHS, the others were just annoying. With such a fact-based, rather than clever or tricky revealer, with nary another answer in sight, it was lightning speed almost all the way.

This week, the Times continues its quest to sign up new subscribers, by making each puzzle to date ridiculously easy, and continuing what seems to be a never-ending roster of debuts, also contributing to the coffers.  Except for a little hiccup in the SW, the fill was subpar. I learned ADIN strictly from crosswords, and there was a ton of four-letter words starting with "A." Not a Thursday-worthy puzzle.

But I did appreciate the clues for ERR  and ALL CAPS.

Enjoyed the theme and the visual/symbolic clues, which I understood as soon as I forced myself to change HELICES to the very unpleasant variant HELIXES to make FREEWAYEXIT fall into place.

The fill was less enjoyable, especially HASAT, ACOUPLE, EMEET and UPFOR.

Overall, a decent debut puzzle that felt (to me) like one that should have run on a Wednesday. Seems like the drought of real Thursday-esque puzzles continues.
I have lived in and committed to NYC for 25 years.  I do not know what a car fare is.

Well. I had pillow CASE then pillow SLIP and finally came up with SHAM

And tennis scoring will forever be a mystery to me. And happily so. 

The Revealer helped a lot but still had to stare at the theme clues for a while. 

Scratching my head at SEXER but OK -- its a dirty job but someone has to do it.

Quite liked BEAR PAW and the clueing for it.

Fun puzzle congrats and cheers to the debut setter.
Thank you for the ASCII art. Keep the arcane crafts alive. But I'm not sure emeet is a thing. (And kind of hope that it isn't)

I always love when the grid gives me some inspiration for my solving soundtrack. Listening to Rhapsody in Blue and being transported, not to the jazz age, but to hearing those American Airlines commercials that were always playing on the Weather Channel in my family‚Äôs kitchen while I got ready for school. 

Anyway, loved this puzzle.

Also plugged in the novel's title first.  NIce debut and congratulations.  Our constructor says, "Thrilled to be sharing my first puzzle in The New York Times!"

So, this is the first puzzle he constructed and it was submitted and accepted?  That is a feat.  Or, are there many more in the NYT pipeline?  Also noteworthy.

Clever!  The theme took me a hot minute, but I got it, and I appreciate the creativity that went into this construction.  That said, the crossing of tennis and racing (34D and 48A) stumped me.  Then again, if Mr. Salvucci had crossed music and ice hockey, I‚Äôd have thought nothing of it.  Once again, (all together now), ‚ÄúYour mileage may vary.‚Äù

Y‚Äôall have a lovely day and give yourselves and one another grace.

Typical tough Thursday for me. I got the 'reveal' right away just from the clue, but needed to work the crosses for all the other theme answers. I was never going to get to those just from the clues. No big deal. Puzzle find today: A Wednesday from April 11, 2001 by Brendan Emmett Quigley. All of the theme clues included the word: "Disoriented." One example: "Disoriented 1949 musical?" WESTPACIFIC And the other theme answers: GONORTHYOUNGMAN EASTDALLASFORTY SOUTHOFEDEN Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/11/2001&g=10&d=D See you tomorrow. ....

Wrong!¬† Jack Kerouac's novel is not where you'll find those entries.¬† Jack liked words.¬† Jack used words.¬† Me too.¬† I like words and I use words.

Because the rest of the puzzle was very, very easy, I never had to figure out what the symbols¬†and icons were trying to tell me.¬† Which is a good thing, because I never would have figured it out.¬† The theme clues might as well have been written in Greek.¬† Well, actually, Greek might have been easier to parse.¬† After all, it consists of words.

I'm reminded of the great Bob Dylan lyric: "And the first one now will later be last."¬† Those who communicate pictorially in keyboard icons will suddenly be more literate than the rest of us.¬† And those of us who use words will be obsolete.
Enjoyable puzzle, now I have to go find a copy of Kerouac's novel.  But please, editors, the sooner you decide to bar cutesy E- prefix words like 50-Down, the better.

Thursday streak-ender for me.  Got the fairly uninteresting theme entries easily enough, but the rest was just a joy-less slog.  Just didn‚Äôt feel like flyspecking anymore and hit reveal puzzle.  On the plus side, having been previously unfamiliar with GUNLAP, researching that led to me to a recent book that resonates.  So not all was lost this morning.  On to tomorrow!

I loved the theme, particularly the revealer (ON THE ROAD), which gave me a twinge of nostalgia: When I was a junior at Northwestern, living in a Rogers Park apartment and driving to campus most days, I often picked up the TA for one of my classes and took him to campus, too. At one point he started talking about a book he was reading, the Kerouac classic in today‚Äôs crossword. I mentioned I‚Äôd like to read it and when he finished, he loaned it to me ‚Ä¶ a paperback with a vibrant yellow cover, which enthralled me from the first sentence. Back then, this being college in the early 1970s, I often went to parties where we smoked a certain substance that was then illegal but which now, at least in my state, one can buy legally at any number of dispensaries. One night during the time I was in the middle of the novel, the ‚Ä¶substance‚Ä¶ came my way. I looked at it and thought, if I do this, I won‚Äôt be able to go home and read the book, and passed it on, and never partook again. I also never returned the book to the TA, which gave me pangs of guilt quite often, as I carried that book with me every day for years, re-reading it often. 

A few years ago, I re-read it after not even dipping into it for decades‚Ä¶and, honestly, I felt no pull at all.

As for the puzzle‚Ä¶I found it moderately challenging for a Thursday, finishing around 40% under my average time.
I kept looking at SEXER thinking there‚Äôs no way that‚Äôs a thing! üòÇ

Well, let's hope that today's Comments are less bone-headed.
To Reply to a Comment, at first be sure you understand what someone has written (and what conclusions you might draw from it) so as to avoid sounding foolish....

I started in the NE thanks to PETA and ALEE (SamE, please note:  this is a word!) FOUR-WAY EXIT?  Almost....but it did cause the PINs to tumble in this game, and I went bowling down the highWAY.

Capital ize?  ist? Still not making sense of 66A.... Ah, YES:  an ISM.

Still a bit easy for a Thursday.  Maybe the Crossworld Gods feel sorry for us due to the weather and all the ice...
Some of the worst fill in recent memory here. APSE AERO ALPO AMFM ADUE ADIN ALEE ASTO ABCS ACHE AIDS ALLY. Seriously? How did this even get published?
There were some fun ones in here, but I strongly feel making me know tennis facts should be punishable with a trip to the hague.

I'm not a huge fan of puns but "Case of emergency" was brilliant! I was really on a roll with this one, and even with an interruption where I forgot to pause the puzzle, I was only 3 seconds off my personal best. I was surprised to see that XWSTATS rated this one as [barely] "hard." Seems like they should have an "average" rating though -- the median solver was only 1% slower than average.
That was a fast Thursday ride!

Got the theme pretty quickly (I used to love ASCII art) and filled in most of the grid rapidly. The only entry actually new to me was GUNLAP. Laughed at ALLCAPS. 

But then, as seems to happen with me a lot recently, I got held up in the NW. Spent almost as long there as the rest of the puzzle put together. At one point I thought maybe "Friend in tough times" was an initialism, and then briefly wondered whether there could be a rebus in that one corner--but there would have to be some logical justification for that related to the theme and I could find none. 

Finally it all fell together. Thursday puzzle is done, time to look for, or create, joy elsewhere in my day. May you find that, too!

Good theme today, a little tougher for people not familiar with Jack Kerouac but once I got TRAFFIC JAM from mostly crossing clues the others had to be a road theme.

The only part of the puzzle I didn't like as much was NW corner.  A SEXER is pretty esoteric knowledge, as is the names of Florida national forests, and I thought HAS AT was an awkward answer for the given clue, and I'm still not sure how HOT DOGS are an answer for showoffs.  Also for a while I thought the tax on imports was LEVY rather than DUTY. 

For the rest of the puzzle all the awkward or esoteric clues had enough easier crossing clues to get them but NW was a lot of awkward clues in the same place.

Another puzzle find. Cute theme - don't recall another one quite like this. Anyway - a Monday from April 14, 2014 by Gareth Bain. Three fifteen letter theme answers in that one, each of them straightforwardly clued: THEREYOUGOAGAIN THEIRFINESTHOUR THEYREGRRRRREAT Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=4/14/2014&g=17&d=A ....

Topologically speaking, when your knickers are in precisely-genomic twists, you can cram a maximal number into an infinite series of frictionless suitcases.

| S | S | S | S | ‚Ä¶

@SP

I hope you change your mind. I'd miss your posts.

BEARPAW was a bit of a letdown, as opposed to BIGFOOT leaving "a large print." It's my second favorite cryptid, after the Snallygaster.

I'm looking forward to the Olympic Biathlon, in which the start of the final "go-round" is signaled by a cowbell, and is known as the bell lap. So I can accept GUN LAP, even though I'd never heard it. (I ran cross country, not track.)
That was really fun!
I came back this morning to read @SP‚Äôs thread only to see that it‚Äôs been taken down. Bad decision, IMHO.

Filled in, but no music.

I was 99% sure that PETA was right.  I doubted SPARE, not having heard of the memoir or understanding the reference.  So I spent some time running letters to make those two work and left it with what seemed the most likely answer, SPARE.  Finally, after a few flyspecking iterations, I discovered my typo MEMEe crossing SPAMMEe.  Still finished 17% faster than average.  

The theme clues had me scratching my head for a bit, but it was a nice moment when the light came on.  Fun puzzle and a good debut.
Congratulations on a great debut, Dario! So clever and so fun!

Good morning! I see I missed some sort of comments dust-up. Without knowing anything, I just feel dismayed when anyone feels like they have to leave. 
Today's theme was fun. Had to pull a couple of U's ! I had highWAY, HELIcES, jolt before TASE. But the crosses set me straight. 
Never even saw the clue for 10D, as it filled itself. Did read the book, though.
Learnt about SALTTAX - looked it up after I finished.
Learnt the SEXER is a thing. 
OK...back to work for me. Have a good day.
SEXIT -   ‚ÄúGood-Bye to All That‚Äù („Éæ (Ôø£ Ôø£) ?
This was delightful!

Sheldon,
You get right back here!
I loved the theme.  My dad worked for WI Department of Transportation Division of Highways and helped design the Interstate system here.  This was right up my alley, or freeway lane.
Fun gimmick, but I could have done without the GUNLAP/ADIN/ADUE intersection.

What fun! I always enjoy the visual clues, even if I don't quite get them at first. Huge 'aha's' when reading Sam's column- which I adore by the way, clever and familiarly quirky (like me, the latter part)- they often make me giggle >:-)

Heir, Air, ERR was delightful, as did that it almost crossed SPARE... made me contemplate and empathize with the challenge and bizarre psychology of growing under those contrasting labels.

Crown and PATE eluded me, even after looking it up- is it a person's name, or a brand of pat√©?
Absolutely loved 30 across!

I almost had to verify answers at the adue/adin/gunlap crosses. From the comments, adin was a bit tricky, but not the others. I am in a definite minority. Who knew so many were well versed in music notation, tennis scoring *and* running race terminology. I am impressed.

Loved the cluing. Looking forward to more from this constructor.

Today's poem made from words found in today‚Äôs puzzle

a/ the dynamic fundamentals of choice
that you‚Äôll find stuffed
in spreadsheets:
radio bands crack dives bible looks slap bag shock wind grassy region slippery tree your turn d/ friend many a friend perhaps definitely played a part played tennis played in the leaves way up in the waiting room played the seven card
a/ for a couple a‚Äô dirt hotdogs
in all caps
Huzzah Dario!  Home sick with the flu and this puzzle was just the thing. Can‚Äôt wait to see your next.
I appreciate the theme but there were some rough patches that felt a bit forced. The GUNLAP/ADIN cross was obscure and brutal, and "sexer" is a bit odd.
Outstanding puzzle w great clues. The ADIN x ADUE x GUNLAP was.... Less than ideal...

Fun theme! I enjoyed this one overall.

But... sexer? Is that a thing?
Too obscure; even after getting it, still didn't get it, on too many.

Music nerdy comment here:
Yes, "A DUE" is used, musically, for "in unison," but only under certain limited circumstances--when two (and only two) instruments are playing from the same staff--two oboes, say, reading from the same part. (I mention oboes, as orchestral woodwinds are often scored in pairs). And then, only when they are both playing the same pitches, and not, say two sets of pitches, but notated on the same staff. "A due" is most often abbreviated "a2." If there are *three* instruments--trumpets, say--playing from the same staff, it would be marked "a tre," or "a3." And if two instruments are reading from the line, but only one of them is supposed to play at that moment, the part would be marked "solo," or more precisely "primo" ("1¬∞") or "secondo" ("2¬∞"), for first or second chair player, respectively. 
The notation gets even more complicated when the two instruments are capable of playing more than one pitch at a time--violins, say. Then the composer/engraver has to be very careful and specific about note-stems, stem-directions, etc.

I love how multiple people can experience the same crossword so differently. From the comments, I can see that many folks struggled with ADUE/ADIN/GUNLAP. For me, that section was a breeze, probably because I had tennis scoring drilled into my brain as a kid. Meanwhile, I was on the struggle bus with HOTDOGS/OCALA/HASAT. Based on the comments, it seems it was a struggle bus of one üòÖ. Just goes to show that we are all on our own solving journeys. Fun puzzle overall!
Really fun one today! I love that we are exploring other ways of making Thursdays tricky and fun other than using a rebus mechanic.
Well done!

What a wonderful debut puzzle. Will be watching for more of your creations in future Dario Salvucci!
I couldn‚Äôt quite believe my eyes when I got the happy music, partly because I had to flyspeck a bit when I was told to keep on trying. I thought the problem must be SEXER, which seemed very odd, but finally discovered it was that TOLLBOOTH, which I had entered correctly earlier, had mysteriously sprouted an incorrect letter, which happens sometimes I find. Also took me some time to figure out GUNLAP. I should have seen that sooner too, as I‚Äôm currently reading a terrific book, ‚ÄúFast Girls‚Äù by Elise Hooper, about the women runners competing in the Olympic Games in 1928 and 1932. It‚Äôs riveting and I highly recommend  it.

Why is TAO always connotated with Confucianism is puzzles? I understand that TAO literally translates to "way," however it is a philosophical rebuttal of Confucian philosophy/structure. I feel like I have seen this multiple times. Is this just an assumption? 

BTW I loved the puzzle, not ashamed that I had to cheat and make sure that SEXER is a real thing, once I finished snickering.
Good puzzle. That is all. :)

Not where I live. Just electronic overhead gantries. Sure, you can occasionally find some, either vestigial or actually in use, in some parts. But we are definitely living through a Great Replacement, akin to the disappearance of pay phones at the beginning of the millennium.

@Jack McCullough
That scam is everywhere. There are no toll roads here in Las Vegas, and I got that one, too, as well as one from E-Z pass, which I haven't had in about 15 years.

@Times Rita

Older folk get rid of cable at their own peril.  Younger folk seem to know where to find broadcast shows without it, but older people don't always know who to ask.  

I used to be able to find the day's Jeopardy on YouTube late that night or the next morning.  Now it's not always there.  

My wife calls the broadcast and cable networks "regular TV," but I told her that within 25 years (maybe even sooner), everything will be streamed, and cable will be a relic like landline phones and actual tollbooths.

Meanwhile, have you considered getting an actual antenna?

@Ggb
I think I mentioned this last time there was a similar clue, but ÈÅì (‚Äútao‚Äù in the now less commonly used Wade-Giles system) is just a fairly bog-standard word in Classical Chinese, about as common as the English word ‚Äúway.‚Äù Taoism, as the name suggests, adopts it as a particular term of art, but you can find it used more generically as far back as the original Analects, with English translators rendering it based on context:

(from James Legge's translation)
Â≠êÊõ∞„ÄÅÁà∂Âú®„ÄÅËßÄÂÖ∂Âøó„ÄÅÁà∂Ê≤í„ÄÅËßÄÂÖ∂Ë°å„ÄÅ‰∏âÂπ¥ÁÑ°ÊîπÊñºÁà∂‰πã*ÈÅì*„ÄÅÂèØË¨ÇÂ≠ùÁü£„ÄÇ
The Master said, "While a man's father is alive, look at the bent of his will; when his father is dead, look at his conduct. If for three years he does not alter from the *way* of his father, he may be called filial."

ÊúâÂ≠êÊõ∞„ÄÅÁ¶Æ‰πãÁî®„ÄÅÂíåÁà≤Ë≤¥„ÄÅÂÖàÁéã‰πã*ÈÅì*„ÄÅÊñØÁà≤Áæé„ÄÅÂ∞èÂ§ßÁî±‰πã„ÄÇ
The philosopher Yu said, "In practising the rules of propriety, a natural ease is to be prized. In the *ways* prescribed by the ancient kings, this is the excellent quality, and in things small and great we follow them.‚Äù

Â≠êÊõ∞„ÄÅÂêõÂ≠êÈ£üÁÑ°Ê±ÇÈ£Ω„ÄÅÂ±ÖÁÑ°Ê±ÇÂÆâ„ÄÅÊïèÊñº‰∫ã„ÄÅËÄåÊÑºÊñºË®Ä„ÄÅÂ∞±Êúâ*ÈÅì*„ÄÅËÄåÊ≠£ÁÑâ„ÄÅÂèØË¨ÇÂ•ΩÂ≠∏‰πüÂ∑≤„ÄÇ
The Master said, "He who aims to be a man of complete virtue in his food does not seek to gratify his appetite, nor in his dwelling place does he seek the appliances of ease; he is earnest in what he is doing, and careful in his speech; he frequents the company of men of *principle* that he may be rectified:‚Äîsuch a person may be said indeed to love to learn."

Given that TAO has more specific connotations in English, a better clue would probably have just been [Chinese ‚Äúway‚Äù].

commentBody:
@Luke

The Tao is a central notion, though very different from Lao-Tzu's, in Confucianism.

@Luke I noted in a reply to someone who posted your same point earlier that the word TAO in Classical Chinese is a pretty generic term that‚Äôs used all over the place outside of Taoism, where it‚Äôs obviously used with a more specific and consistent intent. Given that TAO is usually rendered as such in English mainly in actual Taoist contexts, I agree that the clue probably isn‚Äôt the best. https://www.nytimes.com/2026/02/04/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2026-02-05.html#permid=148651034 There‚Äôs one more example of ÈÅì (TAO) being used in Confucius‚Äôs Analects that I didn‚Äôt include in my earlier comment, but it does oddly fit the theme of this puzzle: Â≠êÊõ∞„ÄÅ*ÈÅì*ÂçÉ‰πò‰πãÂúã„ÄÅÊï¨‰∫ãËÄå‰ø°„ÄÅÁØÄÁî®ËÄåÊÑõ‰∫∫„ÄÅ‰ΩøÊ∞ë‰ª•ÊôÇ„ÄÇ James Legge translates this as: The Master said, ‚ÄúTo rule a country of a thousand chariots, there must be reverent attention to business, and sincerity; economy in expenditure, and love for men; and the employment of the people at the proper seasons." Legge doesn‚Äôt actually translate ÈÅì here, but a more word-for-word rendering of the relevant part could be: ‚ÄúIn a country with a thousand chariots ON THE ROAD‚Ä¶‚Äù

@Nick
(In case anyone else who can read Chinese as written two millennia ago is there, I was being a bit flip in the last part of that comment: ÈÅì is more likely, and conventionally is, parsed as a verb in that sentence above, meaning ‚Äúto lead‚Äù or ‚Äúto rule,‚Äù as it does indeed appear in Legge‚Äôs translation.)

commentBody:
@SBK

I agree about the "turn the computers loose to find something" approach that led to the Biblical Codes episode.  The room numbers struck me as a bit of a reach.   The seven letters in the name Castorp didn't even make their list. Nevertheless  . . .

Here, Mann consciously chooses to insert the number seven prominently.  Most analyses simply mumble about a number traditionally used as a sign of good luck or magical significance but he was acutely aware of the coming Apocalypse of WWI.

I'll stick with my "penetrating insight".üßô

@Al  in Pittsburgh
I support your insight. There's strong support from your points #1 5 7 9b and 10. Those seem to me the more deliberately intended 7s among the elements you listed. The other points seem to me less obvious and perhaps even (/pace/ authorial intent) coincidental?
@Sal :-D

@Andrzej

I, too, know next to nothing about Kerouac‚Äî except for the title of his most famous work. And I don‚Äôt think any more knowledge was needed. In this case, ‚ÄúOn The Road‚Äù just meant traffic.

I share your frustration with the ADUE/AD IN/GUN LAP juncture, though. I used to watch a lot of tennis and I remember commentators saying ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs an AD‚Äù, but I don‚Äôt remember any AD IN or AD Out calls. As for ADUE and GUN LAP, those are brand new to me. I used to watch some Indy car races, but I don‚Äôt recall a gun firing for the final lap. Sounds a little scary. Maybe that‚Äôs a NASCAR thing?

Overall, I found the clueing fairly easy, but as tends to happen for me, the things I didn‚Äôt know were all bunched together. So it goes.

@Tim

Let me edit that for you, since you wanted "scathing":

What was the bigger letdown? The infantile, picture-book theme, fit at best for Tuesday at the kindergarten edition of the NYT, or the straightforward, witless clueing, only made challenging in places by an over-reliance on trivia? I suppose it doesn't even matter as this forgettable excuse for a puzzle will evaporate from my memory by mid afternoon.

Signed - Tim

@Andrzej Ad in is common, vs ad out. I played tennis as a kid (recreationally) and we said it all the time.

That said, it was a Tuesday-Wed difficulty for me. The theme was gettable without even looking at the clues, once I got the obvious Kerouac title and a few crosses.

@Andrzej
Ad in is not something you would hear watching tennis on TV, but recreational tennis, the server calls the score before hitting a serve, and when the server has the advantage, they call out ad in, and if their opponent has the advantage, its ad out.  On TV, the commentators would just say, advantage Alcaraz or, advantage Swiatek.

@Doug

That's pretty niche, ain't it...

@SBK

ADUE/GUNLAP/ADIN defeated me ü§∑üèΩ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Yes it was a dominant performance.  Finding so many daily doubles and winning big bets on them clearly dispirited his two opponents and the games were over quickly.  Very happy to see a puzzle constructor seize the crown.

@Lewis
I was so happy for him! He seemed so modest and unaggressive, the kind of player you love to see win on Jeopardy.  

Along with an extraordinary scope of info and speed on the button, he had Lady Luck on his side.  It's seldom that other players can catch up with a successful, big Daily Double all-in bet, and when a contestant hits three Daily Doubles, as he did on night 2, they are sunk.

Daily Doubles can doom a contestant to lose if they bet it all too late in the game and get it wrong, but he didn't.

@Grant Go here: https://www.nycsubway.org/wiki/New_York_City_Subway_Tokens and much will be revealed. The token's Y is the central letter in "NYC" engraved on the blank, and is the only one punched out. Presumably, the punchout was to reduce tokens sticking to each other.

@BR, this puzzle is the perfect example of the "it takes all kinds" adage! I loved the theme. As soon as I caught on, my eyes brightened and my brain did a Proust as I mentally zoomed back to puzzle books of my childhood. I'm talking about Penny Press and others that were stocked at the supermarket checkout as impulse buys.

I rarely asked my mother for candy but I frequently asked for puzzle books, which she happily bought for me.  And here's the reason for my trip down memory lane: the books had what I've taken to calling old-fashioned rebuses (since learning the crossword meaning of rebus), or visual/picture rebuses.

@Amy FYI, the Erie Canal was not funded by a salt tax. Construction costs were recouped by charging for use of the canal, of which salt was a significant part. Actual salt taxes like those imposed by the British in India were monstrous policies that extracted money from the poor by holding a vital nutrient hostage. The misuse in the clue here is irresponsible, bordering on offensive.

@Niall I get the same feeling with it... I was curious about its origins, and found this: pate (n.1) "top of the head," early 14c. of unknown origin; perhaps a shortened form of Old French patene or Medieval Latin patena, both from Latin patina "pan, dish"; usually employed in a trivial or derogatory sense. Some suggest it may be related to the Old Frisian pote ("skull"). Also referenced in the Bible and Shakespeare's plays... Interesting to know now, though I don't think I'll be using it anytime soon :)

The Erie Canal: A Primary Source History of the Canal That Changed America
Book by Janey Levy

The Erie Canal: A Primary Source History of the Canal That Changed America, by Janey Levy, is a 2003 non-fiction book for middle-grade readers (grades 4-7) that uses primary source documents, illustrations, and narrative to explain how the Erie Canal transformed American transportation, commerce, and settlement. Part of the "Primary Sources in American History" series, the book details the canal's construction as an engineering marvel and its impact on opening the American interior, making New York City a major port, and boosting the nation's economy.
